verses.text: Whoever fears the Lord will do good, and whoever holds to His law will obtain wisdom.
verses.comment: This verse links fearing the Lord with the pursuit of wisdom, echoing themes in Psalms and Proverbs. Obedience brings understanding, signaling the importance of submission to God's teachings.

verses.text: She will meet him like a mother, and receive him as a bride.
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified as a mother and bride here, alluding to the intimacy and nurture of divine truth, and reminiscent of the Church as both mother and bride (see Eph. 5:25-27).

verses.text: She will feed him with bread of understanding and give him the water of wisdom to drink.
verses.comment: Wisdom parallels spiritual nourishment, prefiguring Christ as the bread of life. The sacramental undertones are rich, hinting at how believers are spiritually fed.

verses.text: He will be sustained by her and not fall; he will rely on her and not be put to shame.
verses.comment: Wisdom gives steadfastness. Trusting in divine wisdom saves from shame and failure—another subtle echo of Christ as the source of stability.

verses.text: She will exalt him above his neighbors and open his mouth in the midst of assembly.
verses.comment: Intimacy with wisdom leads to honor and the ability to speak truth before others, foreshadowing the gift of boldness that comes from the Spirit at Pentecost.

verses.text: He will find joy and a crown of gladness, and possess an everlasting name.
verses.comment: The crown alludes to the reward for faithfulness. The everlasting name hints at a participation in eternal life, a theme strongly embraced by the apostolic faith.

verses.text: Foolish people will not approach her, sinners will not see her.
verses.comment: Only the righteous gain wisdom; sin blinds the heart, emphasizing the need for repentance and conversion to approach divine truth.

verses.text: She keeps herself far from pride, and liars never consider her.
verses.comment: Humility is essential for wisdom. Pride and deceit sever one from the deeper mysteries, preparing hearts for authentic reception of the gospel.

verses.text: Praise is not fitting for an unrepentant mouth, for the Lord Himself is the author of wisdom.
verses.comment: True worship requires a pure heart; only those reconciled with God can rightfully give Him praise.

verses.text: Wisdom is given by the Lord, and it prospers with the faithful.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s divine origin points toward the necessity of grace in one’s pursuit of truth and virtue.

verses.text: Do not say, 'It was the Lord who made me go astray,' for He does not do what He hates.
verses.comment: God is never the cause of sin; this serves as a corrective against blaming God for one’s faults, underscoring the importance of free will.

verses.text: Do not say, 'He led me into error,' for He has no need of sinful men.
verses.comment: God desires holiness and righteousness, not sin. He does not tempt nor need anyone to be unrighteous.

verses.text: The Lord hates all abominations, and those who fear Him will not love them.
verses.comment: To fear the Lord is to hate evil, a sign that one genuinely seeks after God’s heart and moral order.

verses.text: He Himself made man from the beginning and left him in the hand of his own counsel.
verses.comment: Free will is highlighted—man can choose to follow the light or darkness, a foundational concept for understanding moral responsibility.

verses.text: If you choose, you can keep the commandments, and to act faithfully is within your power.
verses.comment: Human cooperation with grace is possible; keeping God’s law is a choice, refuting fatalistic interpretations of providence.

verses.text: He has set before you fire and water; stretch out your hand to whichever you choose.
verses.comment: The image of fire and water represents the freedom to choose good or evil, life or death—prefiguring the later teaching of judgment and reward.

verses.text: Before a human are life and death, and whichever pleases him will be given to him.
verses.comment: Choices have lasting consequences; God grants life to those who choose Him.

verses.text: Great is the wisdom of the Lord; He is mighty in power and sees all people.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience sees all actions and choices, ensuring true justice and perfect knowledge.

verses.text: His eyes are on those who fear Him, and He knows every deed of man.
verses.comment: God watches over the faithful and is acquainted with every act, echoing the theme of particular judgment.

verses.text: He has not commanded anyone to be ungodly, and He has not given anyone license to sin.
verses.comment: The passage ends affirming God’s holiness and just governance. Human responsibility, free will, and accountability stand out. The witness to grace and the seriousness of the moral life is unmistakable, subtly affirming doctrines of moral cooperation and the necessity of faith and good works for salvation.
